title: Private NFT Gates - Revelar
description: Projects, particularly game developers, don’t have a way to protect the consumption of public IPFS media enclosed in NFTs.

f6_assessments.q0: Currently, there is no way to protect the consumption of public IPFS media included in the Projects' NFT, especially by game developers. So the proposal wants to develop a Revelar gateway that creates deeper utility around NFT on Cardano at a low cost, a Gateway that can allow logic layers to verify and distribute access to the media in the metadata. . It is aimed at Project users, especially NFT game developers, there is no way to protect the consumption of public IPFS media included in NFT yet.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposed solution is to create a Revelar gateway, which is a managed private IPFS cluster that controls users' access to NFT media content, allowing the content to be controlled as needed. The proposal outlines progress and milestones by month along with specific tasks that need to be completed. The project's core team consists of 3 people: Jason Toevs as CEO / Founder. Jason has a specialization in Mathematics with a focus on Set Theory. He has experience building business systems, scaling software products and teams. Benjamin Beer is CTO, Ben has a background in Computer Engineering and Electronics with a focus on both hardware and software based programming and systems design. He has extensive experience in creating decision support systems. Jacob Christian is the CCO/Co-Founder. He has a major in Entrepreneurship and Integrated Marketing Communications. Jacob is an experienced brand strategist and content creator. Thus, looking at the experience and education of the core team of the proposal, we see that the team is fully capable of ensuring a successful project launch. However, there are still some possible risks. Concerns about centralization with the Revelar portal as a private service on Cardano, NFT standards subject to change and Software delays but the team has also outlined how to fully overcome the risks this.
f6_assessments.q2: The total required budget is 105250$, which is a suitable budget to launch a project to create a private NFT gateway on Cardano. In addition, the budget is explained in detail, specifically for each item of the project, calculated for each number of hours, showing that the proposed group is very close to reality. To keep track of its project progress, the team has Catalyst Coordinator reports including a recorded video, a written version of the updates on a dedicated website, along with applicable demos projects after each sprint (2 weeks). Conclusion: The project is financially transparent.

f6_assessments.q0: The Private NFT Gates-Revelar proposal addresses the Dapps, Products & Integration challenge by building an MVP of the Revelar Gate (control access to your NFT media content). With the low-cost creation and management of these NFTs, a Revelar Gate can allow for logic layers to verify and distribute access to the media within the metadata. The proposal's MVP will cover: "Private NFT" and Custom IPFS storage cluster. The solution is for new and untapped models especially for the NFT game developers. Other DApps can plug and play without having to manage custom IPFS deployment and infrastructure overhead. New DApps can be created at a much faster pace but lower cost. There is no doubt that the project will benefit the ecosystem but it is not open-source code base, the score in impact section reflects this fact.

f6_assessments.q0:
Revelar is a gaming company focusing on the NFT capabilities and the Cardano ecosystem. They have been funded in Fund 7 and Fund 8, and in Fund 9 they are back with two fresh proposals. This one focuses on building a gateway that can control access to NFT content when needed. They are aware that this functionality is not immediately applicable to all stakeholders, but the philosophy behind it is that the more functionalities NFTs can have, the better it will be for the ecosystem’s long term health and development potential. 

So let’s see what benefits can gated NFTs bring: subscription based models, allowing for logic layers that can distribute content differently between multiple parties, private NFTs. The privacy / gated feature will be obtained via private IPFS clusters, basically their own infrastructure. 

Let’s remember that in this challenge the aim should be to foster the development of dapps, products and integrations that can foster adoption, and this use case is definitely a step in the right direction, if it will enable additional use cases for NFTs. A slight question mark should be raised regarding the developers’ appetite for such features which is still untested, but given the wide array of possible applications it’s only fair to infer that there are minimal downsides to the ecosystem for having an extra feature on the table.

Given the still unclear potential of such a feature development, and more importantly, the fact that the technology will not be developed open source (this is confirmed in the proposal itself) and thus of limited use for the wider community at the beginning, I am only offering four stars for its potential impact.
f6_assessments.q1:
Revelar has a great team. The proposal contains selected bios and multiple social media profile and contact information for the most relevant members, and so does their website. They have folks with deep mathematical and engineering backgrounds as well as marketing / business development competencies. They went to great lengths to ensure that this proposal is well understood, since they even created a short video explaining the entire concept behind. 

The team also makes budgeting look easy, with the main expense being hiring additional development resources. Main costs will involve employing a senior engineer and a developer for 12 weeks, at hourly rates of 135 and respectively 73 USD. Minor other costs will fund cloud infrastructure. A strength of the proposal is that the team argues that a few features necessary for this project are already existing within the company so there will be less development needed, minimizing time and money spent. 

Timeline the project should take six months (don’t be confused with the 12 weeks above) and the work will be divided in 12 sprints, with a very logical and reasonable split of activities for each. 

Overall we have a solid team, a very reasonable timeline and budget, and five stars are definitely appropriate for this proposal’s feasibility.
f6_assessments.q2:
There aren’t many Cardano teams that have what Revelar has already established. A dedicated Catalyst website with updates on all of their funded proposals, going back all the way to Fund 7. We have subsections with updates for each, links to the Ideascale pages and extensive dashboards presented where appropriate. So while creating this tool they have definitely positioned themselves as an excellent reference point in terms of how Catalyst reporting should look like. 

Diving down into this proposal’s details, we observe that the team offers excellent success targets: 35 unique gates being created and a 60% retention at the end of the timeline - which are highly relevant and comprehensive items that serve very well their purpose. In conclusion, an excellent auditability implementation, superb Catalyst website and five well deserved stars.

f6_assessments.q0:
Projects, especially game developers, have no way to protect the consumption of public IPFS media included in the NFT. This recommendation is a useful tool for managing private NFTs, controlling access to your NFT media content, and allowing content to be controlled as needed.
The proposal describes the problem clearly and offers an appropriate solution. By creating a design and service that is relatively flexible so that other DApps can plug and play in their applications without having to manage infrastructure costs and custom IPFS implementations. This allows us to empower new DApps created and built within the Cardano Ecosystem much faster at a lower cost. Which increases the functionality and number of potential use cases for Cardano and NFT.
The proposal identifies three main risks including the degree of centralization, NFT standards changes, and software delays. Measures to reduce risk are also appropriately described.
The information provided in the proposal is very specific and comprehensive. I believe this proposal will effectively address the challenge if funded.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal provides a clear, detailed plan with specific tasks to be achieved during the 12x2 week sprint including a schedule and milestones to be achieved every 2 weeks to create an MVP web application production does the following: Creates a "private NFT"; deploy and manage custom IPFS storage clusters on Revelar; specify simple verification rules to authenticate access and display private NFT content to users who meet the verification rules; tools to support/manage creators.
The $105,250 budget is in line with the product they will be offering, the infrastructure cost reductions due to taking advantage of the core services available within Revelar are also taken into account. The entire proposed funding is used to pay the development engineer team for 12 weeks and a small part is the cost of the cloud infrastructure for bandwidth testing ($5,250). However, the budget seems to be working out for 12 weeks - half of the time to complete the proposal, my advice would be for the proposal to include clear details of other funding methods.
The Revelar team is a well-known collaborator and has received funding for several projects in the Catalyst Funds in the past, they are a combination of people with rich experience in building large projects and delivering software-related products. So I believe they will complete the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2:
Like other Revelar projects, they have a dedicated domain for all their Catalyst proposals: https://catalyst.revelar.co - where the community can track the project's progress at any time through demos, documents, and videos are updated regularly at the end of each sprint.
The definition of project success is also well described with specific metrics: deliver an MVP web application as mentioned in the feasibility section and expand to 35 “Gateways” or projects created in the Launchpad access period and cohort retention >60% until the end of the process or project. Success Retention is determined by a Gateway that is visited or used for more than 5 sessions within 7 days.
Given Revelar's history of being very transparent and open to funded projects and the information they provided in this proposal, I believe the community can easily assess and audit the progress and success of the project. I rate 5 for Auditability.

f6_assessments.q0: I think the idea of a subscription-based NFT business model is great. I could see large companies using this as a way to offer subscription services and get rid of the credit card middleman entirely. I would have liked to see some examples of how this could be used in the real world, as I can only make assumptions while reading the proposal. Overall, I am a fan of the idea, yet the proposal could be a bit more substantial.
f6_assessments.q1: The team is made up of highly skilled and experienced game developers. The proposal includes details about the team and the backgrounds and qualifications of the team members. The budget is reasonable and broken down into identifiable milestones and a detailed 6-month schedule with 12x two-week sprints. The budget is a bit high, but reasonable for a team of this caliber. The proposal provides funding of $105250, half of which is to pay the lead engineer at $135 per hour for 12 weeks, which is a high amount compared to other proposals. They have the resources and technical knowledge to make this proposal work, and they have discussed in detail the potential risks, including centralization, NFT standard changes, and software delays, and have identified ways to mitigate them.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal includes a clear timeline, but I lack clearly measurable KPIs.
The time estimate for UI/UX design and architecture design is 2 weeks, which seems high. A more detailed description with more specific budget details would have added more value. The software will also not be fully open source. Therefore, more is needed for verifiability than just regular reporting. Nevertheless, there are sufficient possibilities to overview the status of the proposal via the website.

solution: Enter the Revelar Gate, it’s a managed private IPFS cluster, or gateway, to control access to your NFT media content, allowing for gated content when needed.
